There is no safe path forward to combat the novel coronavirus without adequate testing. Let us hope that out of Dr. Collins‚Äô shark tank will emerge at least one mighty great white shark that will help us combat this disease.
Their success in discovering new technologies to create simple diagnostic tests with quick results‚Äîand then safe and effective treatments and vaccines‚Äîis the only way this will end.
It is likely that at this moment more scientists are working to create solutions to COVID-19 than on any other project in the world.

Thomas Edison said he failed 10,000 times before he produced the first incandescent light bulb. We hope we don‚Äôt have that many failures. But all we need are two or three successes, or even just one.
Many of these early stage concepts won‚Äôt work, or won‚Äôt be able to be scaled up quickly, and that‚Äôs ok.

‚Ä¶to pull out all the stops and fast track new technologies designed to produce tens of millions of tests by August. We allocated another $1 billion to the @BARDA, to work with NIH to accelerate production of these tests.

We worked to include in the most recent coronavirus legislation $1.5 billion for a competitive ‚Äúshark tank‚Äù‚Äì what @NIHDirector calls the Rapid Acceleration of Diagnostics (RADx) Initiative‚Äîto utilize the capacities of government itself, in coordination with the private sector...

Throughout March and April, Senator @RoyBlunt and I had many conversations with experts across the government and the private sector, and couldn‚Äôt find anyone who believed that current technology could produce the tens of millions of tests necessary to put this virus behind us.
There are two ways to increase our testing capacity: We should squeeze every test possible out of current technologies. But second, our focus today, is on the need for new testing technology.

We are now conducting over 1 million diagnostic tests weekly; by mid-June, there will be 2 million to 2¬Ω million available, according to Dr. Deborah Birx, the coordinator of the coronavirus task force.

And the private sector is demonstrating a capacity to turn out quickly tens of millions of serology tests ‚Äî tests to determine whether you have had the disease and have antibodies that might create some immunity, at least for a time.
The administration‚Äôs warp-speed pursuit of a vaccine has a goal of 100 million doses by the Fall and 300 million by January, a target much more ambitious than has ever been achieved before.
The end to this crisis will be determined by three things: tests, treatments, and vaccines. There is promising news that treatments and therapies will be available this summer.

This hearing is about how we will find those new technologies needed to rapidly produce tens of millions of tests in one of the most ambitious scientific enterprises in recent memory, headed by one of our country‚Äôs most distinguished scientists.
But to contain the disease and give confidence to Americans that it is safe to leave our homes, we will need tens of millions of tests, many more than our current technologies can produce.
All roads back to work and back to school lead through testing. Our country will soon be doing 2 million diagnostic tests for COVID-19 a week, an impressive number.

The lines of communication between employers & employees must remain wide open at every step of this transition. Constant consultation will be key.

We need smart, safe, and detailed reopening plans that protect employees & communities & help lead our economy out of this crisis.

But this comes with new responsibilities:

Manufacturers will need to adhere to all recommended public health standards, incl. providing PPE, social distancing, contract tracing, and sick leave policies. 

Workers will need to adhere to these new standards to keep coworkers safe.

Michigan has led the nation in retooling to produce medical supplies and equipment, showing the country our manufacturing base responds when tested.

Now we have the opportunity to show how the manufacturing sector can safely and responsibly re-open in a hard-hit state.

Given the 8th district is home to GM plants in Lansing and Lake Orion, hundreds of other manufacturing facilities, and thousands of skilled workers, it's critical we find the proper balance between re-starting our economy and preserving the health of our workers and families.

.@GovWhitmer's announcement on resuming manufacturing is an important step in the deliberate, careful resumption of our economy.
